questions.question_text:
You have multiple applications running on a compute instance that generate a large amount of log files. You are required to retain these log files for a total of 60 days; at least 15 days on the boot volume, and an additional 45 days in any location.
Which is the most cost-effective way to meet the 15-day boot volume retention requirement and the 60-day total retention requirement?

choices.B: Attach a block volume and use a script that moves log files older than 15 days to the new volume and deletes them completely after 60 days.
choices.A: Do not delete any logs but resize the boot volume of the instance every time additional space is needed.
choices.C: Create an Object Storage bucket and use a script that runs daily to move log files older than 15 days from the boot volume to the bucket. Create a lifecycle rule for the bucket to delete any logs over 60 days old.
choices.D: Terminate the instance while preserving the boot volume. Create a new instance from the boot volume and select a DenseIO shape to take advantage of the local NVMe storage.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
confirmed via documentation C

Selected Answer: C
confirmed via documentation C
c is the correct answer

comments.content: Admin sorry wrong post. please delete.

discussion.content:
Enabling Object Storage replication is as simple as creating a replication policy on the source bucket that identifies the region and the bucket to replicate to. After the replication policy is created, the destination bucket is read-only and updated only by replication from the source bucket. Objects uploaded to a source bucket after policy creation are asynchronously replicated to the destination bucket. Objects deleted from the source bucket after policy creation are automatically deleted from the destination bucket. Objects uploaded to a source bucket before policy creation are not replicated.

https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Object/Tasks/usingreplication.htm

Selected Answer: C
confirmed via documentation C

confirmed via documentation B

I agree with D.

D. Allow group NetworkAdmins to manage virtual-network-family in compartment A:B:C

Only compartment A is visible in the root tenancy so you cannot directly assign it to C.

Selected Answer: A
Allow group NetworkAdmins to manage virtual-network-family in compartment C
The requirement is only for compartment C, not all.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
To attach this policy to the tenancy, write this policy statement that specifies the path from CompartmentA to CompartmentC:

Allow group NewtworkAdmins to manage virtual-network-family in compartment CompartmentA:CompartmentB:CompartmentC

https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Identity/Concepts/policies.htm

Selected Answer: D
It is D

correct answer is D

Selected Answer: D
the answer shold be D

 If you attach the policy further up the hierarchy, you must specify the path. The format of the path is each compartment name (or OCID) in the path, separated by a colon:


<compartment_level_1>:<compartment_level_2>: . . . <compartment_level_n>
To attach this policy to the tenancy, write this policy statement that specifies the path from CompartmentA to CompartmentC:

Allow group NewtworkAdmins to manage virtual-network-family in compartment CompartmentA:CompartmentB:Compart

questions.question_text:
You are in the process of migrating several legacy applications from on-premises to Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI). The current servers are already virtualized. However, you notice that the version of CentOS currently running does not align with any of the Oracle-provided compute images.
How would you migrate your existing virtual server images to OCI?

choices.D: Export your current image in the VMDK format and copy to an Object Storage bucket. Import it as a custom image. Select native mode to ensure the best possible performance.
choices.B: Export your current image in the QCOW2 format and copy to an Object Storage bucket. Import it as a custom image. Select emulated mode to ensure compatibility with legacy drivers.
choices.A: Export your current image in the VDI format and copy to an Object Storage bucket. Import it as a custom image. Select native mode to ensure the best possible performance.
choices.C: Export your current image in the QED format and copy to an Object Storage bucket. Import it as a custom image. Select emulated mode to ensure compatibility with legacy drivers.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
confirmed via documentation A

Selected Answer: D
confirmed via documentation D

Selected Answer: B
The answer is B

I think the correct answer is B '' Both VMDK and QCOW2 are supported. However, in the lunch mode you have to either select Paravirtualized mode or Emulated mode: refer to below link : https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Compute/Tasks/importingcustomimagelinux.htm

Selected Answer: B
Format to

choices.B: Bring your own image and use it as a template for the new instances.
choices.A: Use Oracle-provided images and customize the installation using a third-party tool.
choices.D: Create a custom image and use it as a template for the new instances.
choices.C: Select an image from the OCI Marketplace.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
confirmed via documentation C

Selected Answer: D
confirmed via documentation D

Selected Answer: D
Option D: "Create a custom image and use it as a template for the new instances" would allow you to achieve the task with the least amount of effort.

By creating a custom image from your existing running instance, you essentially capture the exact configuration and software setup of that instance. Then, you can use this custom image as a template to launch multiple new instances with identical configurations and installed software. This approach streamlines the process and ensures consistency among the new instances.

Selected Answer: D
Already the instance exists in OCI

questions.question_text:
You just got a last minute request to create a set of instances in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI). The configuration and installed software are identical for every instance, and you already have a running instance in your OCI tenancy.
Which image option allows you to achieve this task with the least amount of effort?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
confirmed via documentation B

Selected Answer: A
confirmed via documentation A

Selected Answer: C
C. Use consumer group high for month-end jobs and consumer group medium for data analytics.

By assigning the consumer group "high" to month-end jobs and the consumer group "medium" to data analytics tasks, your customer can effectively prioritize the resource allocation for these two types of workloads. This ensures that month-end jobs, which are critical and resource-intensive, get higher priority, while data analytics tasks are allocated resources at a medium priority level. This configuration helps balance the workload and ensures that the critical month-end jobs have the necessary resources to complete efficiently.

choices.B: Use consumer group high for both month-end jobs and data analytics.
choices.C: Use consumer group high for month-end jobs and consumer group medium for data analytics.
choices.D: Use consumer group medium for month-end jobs and consumer group low for data analytics.
choices.A: Use consumer group high for data analytics and consumer group low for month-end jobs.

questions.question_text:
Your customer would run month-end jobs on their on-premises databases that would take around 14 hours to complete and sometimes even fail due to overloaded database systems. After a detailed evaluation, they migrated their database to Oracle Autonomous Data Warehouse. They realized they could also move their analytics platform to Oracle Analytics Cloud (OAC) and have their best of breed technology platforms meet their critical business requirements.
After migrating their analytics platform, they want to use one consumer group for running month-end jobs and another consumer group that can be used by the analytics team for performing data analytics tasks everyday.
How can your customer implement this requirement?
